question.title: Will the CDC-reported cumulative number of confirmed U.S. measles cases in 2026, as of April 24, 2026, be at least 2,000?
question.description:
A very high measles case count would indicate a major outbreak year with implications for vaccination campaigns, public health capacity, and travel/education policy.

`{"format":"bot_tournament_question","info":{"hash_id":"f3f1d0fc7ac87c72","sheet_id":186.0}}`
question.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as Yes if, l the CDC-reported cumulative number of confirmed U.S. measles cases in 2026, as of April 24, 2026, is at least 2,000. It resolves using the CDC “Measles Cases and Outbreaks” page at [https://www.cdc.gov/measles/data-research/index.html](https://www.cdc.gov/measles/data-research/index.html). The relevant value is the cumulative number of confirmed U.S. measles cases for 2026 shown on the CDC page for the update reflecting reports  for that date. The outcome is Yes if that cumulative 2026 count is ≥ 2,000.
question.fine_print: Use confirmed cases according to CDC (not media totals, state totals, or non-confirmed/probable cases). If the CDC does not publish an update dated April 24, 2026 by the resolution time, Metaculus may use the most recent CDC update published after the time the question opens and before May 1, 2026, as long as it encompasses any full week in April 2026
question.short_title: Will the CDC-reported cumulative number of confirmed U.S. measles cases in 2026, as of April 24, 202
